0:11



This method of writing the model was implemented to keep it as simple as possible to display and interpret. To see the full model in linear form, check Section¬†7.2 in the appendix. We shall, additionally, run this model across more restricted sets of data, first, concerning only our countries of interest, and second, variants concerning only pre-2004 ascension EU members to identify any unique results from applying different data restrictions alone. Think of it as robustness checks for some very pitiful results. All are run only for the subset period prior to May 2004.
Our parameter of interest remains the unemployment rate, \(u\), and its relationship with our outcome, as per the traditional Phillips curve relationship. The unemployment rate is collected for working-aged individuals (15 to 64) across states and is not harmonized. Per that same consideration, absent what we saw earlier in Figure¬†1, we would expect that the effect of unemployment on inflation is negative. Looking back at Figure¬†1, it is clear that some of our countries follow that trend, and with more variables included to account for some of the variation in the outcome, we could see that be generalized. But such an outcome is doubtful, and, in truth, the result is likely that the curve fails to apply in general‚Äîat least for the baseline.
There are, of course, problems with this model. Chief among them is the question of stationarity which ever-hangs over when using plain inflation as a variable. Implementing a rolling mean across some of the lags does help to assuage us of the worst fears, but even there, we can see that the means among the two (of course, given one is a mean of the other) align, and differ principally in their ranges of values and variability. Moreover, seeing as out baseline considers all countries, and does not consider variation in how unemployment reverberate throughout their respective economies (something that a time-varying unemployment gap would, in-part, handle), we are sure to see many different unemployment rates crossing many different levels of headline inflation. That would track with what we saw in Figure¬†1 and does not spell favorable outcomes for our first regressions. The baseline model is hampered by the fact that it is being applied to a pool of many countries and by the lack of valuable pieces of information, like the time-varying natural rates of unemployment.

title: Ready to Join?
text:
4.2 Joining the EU
The model implemented for the purposes of this section is quite the same as the baseline in Equation¬†1, but now restricted to consider countries in two, distinct, periods and among two distinct subsets. This does not change the baseline estimating equation much, except that it treats our panel data more like a panel should we choose to run this all in one go. Per our earlier analysis, we would expect the coefficient on our parameter of interest, \(u\), remain consistent with the traditional Phillips curve relationship (assumed from Gylfason and Hochreiter (2022)), if not become more acute in that relationship. This is because: among countries not in, or not joining, the EU, they should not experience a serious change from the 2004 ascension (all else constant, and given that the states joining were not major world players), and countries that were already in the EU should have had their adjustments at whatever earlier times they joined‚Äîprior to the new wave of ascensions. In this way, countries who are not actively joining the EU, are not in the treatment group, so we split along those lines. To achieve this, we segment the data by two dummy variables (seen in Table¬†2): one, identifying EU membership prior to 2004 (but since 2001, pre2004member), and another identifying EU membership post-2004 (inEU2004, which is also equal to the value of pre2004member for countries prior to the ascension date). Given that our range is from 2001 to the beginning of 2007, and no countries left the EU in that period, nor did any join except in 2004, we can use these two dummies alone to successfully carve up our data as we would like (for example, the join-ers will have pre2004member + inEU2004 = 1 in the post-ascension period, whereas non-join-ers and existing members will have it = 0 and = 2, respectively). This extension will be considered with all lags to unemployment applied as in the baseline. Alongside our results from these subsets, we will apply a naive (‚Äúnaive‚Äù as in, just appending a treatment and time dummy and their interaction to it) difference-in-differences variation of the model, adding terms to identify a time post ascension, and treatment (the act of joining), and the interaction of the two, to the model.

Looking first at Table¬†3 (a), with an adjusted \(R^2\) of 0.886. First, as noted in the footnote, all model variables were included in these regression, but the output was truncated to our parameter of interest and its lags. The full tables are available in Section¬†7. The coefficients on underlying inflation and its shocks were consistent with expectations based in Gordon‚Äôs prior works, and otherwise not worth much discussion. The contemporaneous unemployment term is nearly significant at the 10% level11, but is not so. These results disappointingly do not tell much more than that the relationship is generally insignificant‚Äîeven the distribution of coefficients through time is only in the context of our window. Per the model, all else constant, a one percentage-point increase in unemployment, \(u\), in period \(t\), would on average see a -0.016 percentage-point decline in the contemporaneous headline rate of inflation. Period \(t\) would next become period \(t-1\), where, on average and else constant, that same one percentage-point increase would see a 0.007 percentage-point increase in the headline rate of inflation. This would continue down the line for each period in time, until the the final lagged period, \(t-11\), whereupon the average effect (if we want to roughly entertain this idea), where all else was held through all periods, totals to approximately a reduction of 0.16 percentage-points in headline inflation. This may sound like it is worth something in terms of economic significance, but that is conditioned by the fact that many of these coefficients are either: very small in magnitude, insignificant, have relatively large standard errors, or fit all of the above.
Considering a variation of Equation¬†1 across the same subset as Table¬†3 (a) that contains no lags on unemployment (only including the contemporaneous term), we arrive at a, frankly sorrowful, and entirely insignificant, coefficient of 0.0088188 on \(u_t\), with a standard deviation (0.0088657) larger than itself. This outcome is of course not an apples-to-apples comparison with the prior model, as we are deliberately losing some information in the process, but it helps to paint a picture of general insignificance. In fewer words, the traditional Phillips relationship fails when applied across our whole dataset, and we fail to reject the null that the rates of unemployment and inflation are particularly linked among a broad set of economies. Insignificant terms, low coefficients, and relatively high standard errors across the board.
Again, considering Figure¬†1, this is not a particular surprise. Similarly, if we consider a subset containing only our countries of interest Table¬†3 (b), the result is similarly muddled in insignificance and in fact is even worse in that respect‚Äîdoing little to help the ‚Äúcause of the curve‚Äù here either. One point of note that we do find in Table¬†3 (b), is that the first lag of unemployment is significant and of comparatively-large magnitude among other coefficients across the three tables. However, it is just as soon countered by an equally and oppositely significant coefficient on a further lag, amounting to more moot. It may be difficult to understand how puny these magnitudes are, so simply know that in Gordon (2013), the coefficient unemployment gap in his ‚ÄúTriangle‚Äù implementation was significant and negative at roughly -0.5, and even his New-Keynesian Phillips Curve models (largely similar, just not having all the same shocks and time-varying accessories) using the traditional unemployment rate, had coefficients that were significant and negative at roughly -0.19.
Lastly, considering a subset restricted to only include countries in the EU prior to the 2004 ascension Table¬†3 (c), we arrive at the least disappointing result of the three. The coefficient on the contemporaneous unemployment rate for that period is negative and significant at the 5% level‚Äîand, though still quite small in magnitude, not nearly so as the prior two cases. Most of the coefficients are negative, and a handful are significant. This is the only case where there is arguably a non-vestigial Phillips relationship. Considering the coefficients as in Table¬†3 (a), for a one percentage-point increase in unemployment, \(u\), in period \(t\), on average an else constant we would expect to see a decline of 0.0532792 percentage points in the rate of inflation, followed be a series of downstream lagged declines (or sometimes slight increases, although all of those are basically insignificant) in the next periods of inflation. Among some countries, surely, the curve is present, and perhaps the strongest case for applicability is the EU (despite the low magnitudes), but a rule is not a rule if you must pick and choose its applicability.
Whatever the case, it appears that the Phillips relationship is not very strong in aggregate these days, but that does not deny us a comparison between the pre- and post-periods.

This coefficient on the treatment is just a fixed effect dummy, so it only flips on or off, but recall that the average rate of inflation across the whole data is 2.6 percentage points Table¬†2, and this dummy has a coefficient of 0.80. If we consider a truly naive model (as in Table¬†5 (b)), by contrast, governed entirely by the treatment and period dummies and their interaction, we see what Table¬†5 (a) hinted in its full cruelty: inflation was higher, on average, among the join-ers in the post-ascension period. This naive model is not meant to really ‚Äúmodel‚Äù things, but rather to demonstrate the dynamics of these subsets in the simplest possible way. And what is tells us is to expect higher inflation among join-ers, and that is something supported both by our direct comparisons in Table¬†4 and in our (compared to the naive model) more realistic implementation in Table¬†5 (a).
To summarize. The Phillips relationship is not present, and even if it was, our strongest evidence from our various models suggests that join-ers saw their national rates of inflation grow upon their ascension. Considering all our model variations in sum, we find little evidence of a consistent Phillips curve relationship among any of the three primary groups: join-ers, existing members, and non-members, and find most evidence for a growth in inflation (tenuously, possibly, related to growth in unemployment, bucking the expected trend) among join-ers in the post-ascension period. If there is a traditional Phillips curve relationship to be found, this model has proved poor in ascertaining it. Our hunch, is that this is the result of missing key components of Gordon‚Äôs model that he had made serious use of. Chief among them: the time-varying rate of natural unemployment, and the unemployment gap.
As described in Section¬†2.3, the unemployment gap contains information on more than just labor. It is derived using the unemployment rate and core inflation, meaning that it contains information on both and varies with both through time. But it is also not sufficient to simply substitute in core inflation alongside the unemployment rate, because that overlooks their dynamic. No, there is a reason Gordon calculates the model by that method, and as noted again in Section¬†2.3, it demonstrably leads to results that are closer to expectations (Gordon 2013). But it is no matter, as a final extension, in the appendix, Section¬†7.1, we throw all the fixed-effects in the world at the model and see what that does (it helps!). But first, we shall conclude our principal findings.

title: Ready to Join?
text:
7.1 A DiD Diversion
As a final bit of fun, we include country-level fixed effects into the model and run a triple interaction on that term, the dummy term for EU members pre-ascension, and another dummy for members post-ascension. Including a table for this here would be a nightmare, so check Section¬†7 for that. But, one thing worth noting is that when looking at the fixed effects by country, the coefficient on Lithuania is quite small in magnitude (not negative, but small) among its peers. For example, the coefficient on Lithuania was insignificant at 0.1416405 with a standard error double that (0.3122093), whereas its neighbor to the North and fellow joiner Latvia had a significant coefficient of 1.6107148 with a standard error of about the same magnitude. Perhaps the assertions of Gylfason and Hochreiter (2022) are justified in the particular case of Lithuania!

title: Global Trade and Vulnerability
text:
1.1 A Whole Lot of Nonsense
Just about one-hundred days into his second presidential administration, Donald Trump has investors pleading that he roll back new trade and tariff policies that have been, thus far, met with near-universal apprehension (at minimum) by American firms, American trade partners, and to a disappointingly lesser extent1, American consumers. Quarterly real GDP (gross domestic product) growth has dipped into the red for the first time in two years (2025) and most of these tariffs were only announced in April. We do not know where this will go, because we are still living with it, and the current roll-out of this policy has been about as consistent as anything else done under either Trump administration. As of early May, there is a ‚Äúpause‚Äù in the excising of these new tariffs for ninety days, but it is hard to know what will come after that, among all the rhetoric. For the purposes of this paper, we will suppose that‚Äîeven if they are toned down considerably‚Äîthese new tariffs will come back into effect after the the pause expires. That would be a bad idea, and we need not look far to see why these policies such a bad idea‚Äîbut this administration is no stranger to bad ideas.








Figure¬†1: Effective Tariff Rate (USA), 1790 Onwards

title: Global Trade and Vulnerability
text:
1.2 From the Frontlines
Here, we shall reflect on anecdotes sourced from a video report released in April by Burke et al. (2025) and from Meer (2025). These anecdotes are for the purposes of illustrating the effects of these tariffs in particular when too little time has really passed for much hard data. They are necessarily incomplete pictures, but provide accounts consistent with others (including others from Burke et al. (2025) who includes many interviews from many firms in their report).

1.2.1 HYTE and the Cost of Tariffs
Considering as case in the consumer electronics space: personal computer cases and accessories company HYTE‚Äîin a rare case for the industry‚Äîinvited Steve Burke of Gamers Nexus to the headquarters and permitted him look at the real costs of tariffs (as of mid-April) for their business. Here are some stylized facts from Burke et al. (2025), with numbers rounded-off:

Before the imposition of new (post-2018) tariffs on Chinese imports, HYTE‚Äôs margins were already quite thin, turning a profit of roughly only $5 per ‚ÄúY40‚Äù series computer case‚Äîa 5% margin when considering the 25% margin cut taken by retailers.
Following the imposition of the first round of new tariffs on Chinese imports in February (10%), landed costs for HYTE grow from from about $92 to $99, with a ‚Äútariff charge‚Äù of $7. This alone turns the slim 5% profit into a 2% loss (if the same price of $130 is maintained).
At the highest end (125% reciprocal plus other tariffs), as of the date HYTE had revealed their cost structure for the Y40, the tariff charge becomes roughly $121, and the landed costs balloon to nearly $215 dollars. For a case that HYTE had charged $130 (and made a small profit on), the landed costs could reach nearly double that sale price.




It is difficult to stress how destructive these kinds of tariff policies are, particularly for more ‚Äúniche‚Äù consumer electronics firms that neither have the brand strength, the productive capacity, or the fiscal coffers to weather them. Quoting Rob Teller, Product Director at HYTE (Burke et al. 2025):

[‚Ä¶] so, you can imagine now, if you add any tariff to this [Y40 series cost structure], the response isn‚Äôt‚Äîlike‚Äî‚Äòoh, we need to go and re-imagine how we build these things,‚Äô it‚Äôs [instead] ‚Äòthis product is non-viable, we can‚Äôt sell products at this price anymore‚Äô [‚Ä¶] this market, as it stands today [mid-April, 2025] with these products, it‚Äôs not viable to manufacture and bring these products to sell in America.



\(~\text{}~\)





Y40 Case Cost Structure, Burke et al. (2025)





This problem is not something remedied by ‚Äúsimply‚Äù moving production to the United States. First, such a move takes considerable investment‚Äîinvestment which firms like HYTE, and many others, do not have the cash reserves to investigate (Burke et al. 2025) for their industries. Second, even if such a move is possible for all these firms, consumers do not buy things made in the United States. If given the choice to buy the same thing for less money, even the most patriotic are unlikely to spend much more for the pleasure. This is epitomized by A/B pricing tests for products, which are being run by some firms, in this new age, to assess how moving to US-production would pan out. Among such firms, is Afina.


1.2.2 Afina and American Production
Afina is a company producing filtered shower-heads. Their product is something that, in all honesty, is simple to manufacture today. This is by no means an insult‚Äîand perhaps their founder may disagree‚Äîbut my point stands that these are products that should not be difficult to manufacture in most places. And this is true! Afina was able to find a domestic (in the United States) manufacturer to partner and produce their shower-heads. However, this manufacturer, has much higher operating costs than Afina‚Äôs overseas partner, so Afina wanted to know how a commensurate price increase on their final product would affect sales. To investigate this, Afina ran an A/B test: offering their product at two prices depending on if they were made in ‚ÄúAsia‚Äù (China and Vietnam) or the United States (Meer 2025). Below is a summary of the details and results of this test:

The shower-head, when manufactured in China and Vietnam, can be sold at a profit for $129 dollars. To maintain the same margin with the same shower-head‚Äîbut have it made in the United States‚Äîthe ‚ÄúMade in USA‚Äù variant is sold for $239 dollars.
When visitors came to the site, they were offered the choice to purchase either variant, in the same menu, with all other things left untouched. Per Afina (Meer 2025), ‚Äúthe results were sobering.‚Äù Out of a sample of 25,650 site visitors, zero purchased the shower-head at the ‚ÄúMade in USA‚Äù price, and only 24 even added that option to their cart (compared to 3,560 who added the ‚ÄúMade in Asia‚Äù version to their carts and 584 among those who bought at the lower ‚ÄúMade in Asia‚Äù price).

Here is a graph putting words to shape to further stress just how stark this is:








Figure¬†2: A/B Test: Shopper Behavior by Country of Origin and Price





Do not be fooled! The average consumer will not choose to spend more money than they need to, and they will not be happy with price hikes.


1.2.3 What This Means
HYTE and Afina are but a few wounded firms, in specific industries, among a wide spectrum of potential outcomes. But still, from these anecdotes, a narrative does arise. In general, tariffs hurt the margins of firms and thus incur price hikes on consumers. Smaller firms, or ones operating in more niche spaces, cannot afford such hikes. These firms rely on winning over customers by price. When they cannot do so, as Robert Teller at HYTE said (Burke et al. 2025), then they cannot afford to sell in the United States. This means fewer options at higher prices (prices which consumers are less likely to tolerate except in the case of ‚Äúnecessary‚Äù goods). This likely means less consumption expenditures, and by extent, likely an aggregate loss to welfare. And this is a case forming in the United States‚Äîthe richest country on the planet. In fewer words, nations are vulnerable to their own erections of tariffs. As such, this paper assesses the vulnerability of nations to their own tariffs. To this end, we reflect on prior works concerning gains from trade and take them as a theoretical standard. We then:

Make some underlying assumptions about gains related to those works;
Define what vulnerability means in the context of this paper; and
Construct a novel estimation model to assess how vulnerable a given country is per ‚Äúunit‚Äù increase of tariff trade barriers;

title: Global Trade and Vulnerability
text:
2.1 Melitz (2003)
To say Professor Marc Melitz changed how trade was studied would be an understatement, particularly in terms of industry-level estimations. From Melitz (2003), we have a particular takeaway that is relevant to this paper:

Increases to trade openness, where more firms compete in the trade environment, map to ‚Äú[‚Ä¶] market shares and profits [being] reallocated towards the more efficient firms‚Äù.

This is an empirically robust finding, backed in principle by the likes of Ramondo and Rodr√≠guez-Clare (2013). To stretch this finding into a useful assumption we can say that tariffs restrict trade openness. By induction this leads to a reduction in firm-level (and more broadly, industry-level) competition, and by extent to a less efficient allocation of market shares and profits at the firm and industry levels. This is a not novel connection! This is a core tenet of the policies underlying and supporting trade liberalization, but it is good to have it said and have empirical backing for it. Ramondo and Rodr√≠guez-Clare (2013) in particular, consider variations including multi-national production with trade itself, and find strong results in favor. Again, this is not novel, but we need it as a baseline for my model to make sense.

title: Global Trade and Vulnerability
section: 2.2 Brandt et al. (2017) and Frankel and Romer (1999)
text:
2.2 Brandt et al. (2017) and Frankel and Romer (1999)
In their respective works, Brandt et al. (2017) and Frankel and Romer (1999) both take econometric approaches to estimating the gains (losses) from openness (closed-ness). In the latter case, authors Frankel and Romer focus on national proximity as a characteristic influencing trade and implement an instrumental variable estimation approach. This mind to proximity is intuitive, and something understood and applied across many similar works. Ideally, for our own model we would replicate their instrumental approach, but that is difficult with our chosen path. Moreover, with the data we do have, it is not necessary to construct an instrument. This is further-discussed in Section¬†4.2. In terms of aggregate welfare, Brandt et al. (2017), explore losses from the 2018 US-China trade war, and indeed find some‚Äîmarginal‚Äîlosses. This is in line with theory, and Frankel and Romer (1999) if we consider losses in a counter-factual to gains, and particularly gives us a recent comparison from the United States.

title: Global Trade and Vulnerability
text:
4.1 Data
All data is sourced from the WB and WTO for the United States, China, and India2 over a period from 2001 (the admission of China to the WTO) to 2019. We additionally collected data for the year 2000 on imports and exports for the purposes of the first-differences in import and export figures. For bilateral trade we source from the WTO, and for MFN rates we do the same. For income (GDP), we take the world bank averages by country and by year. For the MFN (most-favored nation) rates by country, we take a yearly simple average across countries (reporters), to turn conform the monthly MFN observations with our yearly WB data. Among the data bilateral, countries are split into ‚Äúreporters‚Äù and ‚Äúpartners,‚Äù which will be paired into bilateral-pairs for the purposes of the model. Below are some summary statistics3:

title: Global Trade and Vulnerability
text:
4.2 Model
As outlined earlier, the model is not particularly complex. We use tariffs, which are represented by MFN observations, and bilateral aggregate trade growth to estimate income. One may think that these MFN tariff rates and trade (particularly imports) are related, and that there could be issues as a result in a traditional OLS estimation. However, if we account for trade groups (e.g., add an interaction term for the pairs of countries) to a regression of the MFN rates by imports, exports, or the total exchange, the results all return with the the three being insignificant with high p-values. When regressing only by those terms and dropping the interaction, some results come back as significant but the magnitude is tiny and we simply know that these regressions amount to little. In truth, MFN and the tariff rates are not very closely related, and that is demonstrated aptly by the below graph:








Figure¬†3: MFN Rates Compared to Trade





The relationship seen in Figure¬†3 is the exact opposite of what we would expect to see were the two related closely (for an example of what we would roughly expect, see Frankel and Romer (1999)). Of course, if we were looking at other tariff rates this would likely be different, but the MFN rates are what we are equipped to use. Below is the regression output for first-differenced total exchange on the MFN rates with bilateral-pair fixed-effects and their interaction:

With these considerations in mind, we run a model using bilateral country-pair fixed effects and their interactions for total trade exchange changes and MFN rates. We continue to use changes, rather than the contemporaneous total, because it allows us to consider adjustments in totals through time. Our estimation equation is detailed below:
\[
Y_{t} = \Delta \text{Trade}_{t} + \text{Tariff}_{t} \times \text{CountryPair}_{jk}
\tag{1}\]
where for countries \(j\) and \(k\) in time \(t\), the average tariff imposed is \(\text{Tariff}\), the lagged growth in aggregate bilateral trade is \(\Delta \text{Trade}\), and the bilateral pair is \(\text{CountryPair}\). Rather than segmenting the MFN rates and tariffs by country, we consider them in aggregate but apply our fixed-effects for the bilateral pair. This is a less precise estimation, but it keeps the interpretations simple. Tariffs in this period are assumed to be new impositions, this will not be true across all cases but is a simplifying assumption.

As seen in Table¬†2, the coefficient on MFN rates is both statistically significant (at the 0.1% level) and negative with a large magnitude. MFN rates are in percentage points, and range in the dataset up to roughly 32%, while income is a pure level. Considering how simple the model is, do not take the values as some truism, but the magnitude and significance speak to our core point: tariffs have a negative effect.
